posts.name: Tyler Park
posts.cooked: i kinda have basic java coding down but i still feel lost and clueless with coding. anywhere online thats good at teaching it and to help me understand it better? i want to hopefully try and start working with motors or even my teams other robots i dont think it helps i have like no prior experience to any coding, except maybe a little C ++ i did last year in a class but thats it

posts.name: sam liu
posts.cooked: w3schools is the great place to learn java coding.  And if you want to learn more about FRC specific programming, there is FRC 0 to autonomous .

posts.name: Riley Brewer
posts.cooked:
This is my prefered resource:

An introduction to computer science

Jetbrains is also good:

Solve algorithmic problems, work with Swing and Spring Boot, learn about blockchain, neural network, and encryption, and more.

posts.name: Brad
posts.cooked: Fec ladder has a series of coding videos on coding. Then on the site some review questions https://www.frcladder.com/

posts.name: Jeffrey Davis
posts.cooked:
Once you get through the zero to robot on wpilib, I recommend wpilib docs on whatever interests you.

Once you have some ideas, read the github of a few of the open alliance teams. Find one’s that do similar stuff and just check it out. Also, ask them questions. Most of the teams want to help. Hook up with other teams and ask them specifics. It really works. A lot of their code is real and raw and works because it’s battle tested rather than theoretical.

Also, I can’t stress enough, get something working so it’s fun and then iterate. Start with moving a motor, then some wheels, then driving and just keep adding. Don’t stress about perfect or the way. Just figure things out at first. You can always edit and fix when you understand later.

posts.name: Tyler Park
posts.cooked: Update: one last thing I forgot to mention, I’m on a macbook pro

posts.name: John Hascall (he)
posts.cooked: It is my experience that most FRC teams use VS Code as their editor and that is available for OSX Running Visual Studio Code on macOS

link_counts.title: Running Visual Studio Code on macOS

posts.name: Jim Sokoloff
posts.cooked:
john3928:

most FRC teams use VS Code as their editor

This is true, but I would definitely recommend using the WPILib installer and install the VSCode that that installer offers to install (even alongside another VSCode install that you might have).

There are a bunch of handy config/utilities that that installer provides that the vanilla VSCode doesn’t. (I’m sure there’s a way to create them, but I’d just take the installer that almost everyone else is using.)

link_counts.title: WPILib Installation Guide — FIRST Robotics Competition documentation
